title: Meningioma (WHO Grade I, II, III)
icd10: D42.9 (Neoplasm of uncertain behavior of meninges
D42.0 (Neoplasm of uncertain behavior of cerebral meninges)
scope: ** Comprehensive management of newly diagnosed and recurrent meningiomas (WHO grades I, II, and III) in adults. Covers incidental discovery, symptomatic presentation, neuroimaging evaluation (MRI with gadolinium, CT), observation criteria for asymptomatic/small meningiomas, surgical planning (including skull base approaches), stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) and fractionated radiation therapy, perioperative management (dexamethasone, seizure control), recurrence monitoring with serial MRI, and grade-specific treatment strategies. Excludes pediatric meningiomas, radiation-induced meningiomas (separate etiologic consideration but same management), and spinal meningiomas (briefly referenced but distinct surgical approach).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Pre-operative baseline; platelet count for surgical candidacy; leukocytosis screen if infection differential
Renal function for contrast imaging; hepatic function baseline for medications; electrolyte assessment; glucose baseline before dexamethasone
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; anticipate glucose elevation with dexamethasone

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulopathy assessment for surgical candidacy; pre-operative clearance
Steroid-induced hyperglycemia baseline if dexamethasone initiated; pre-operative assessment
Pre-operative for craniotomy; anticipate intraoperative blood loss especially for vascular skull base meningiomas
Fatigue differential; baseline before radiation therapy if planned; pituitary axis assessment if parasellar meningioma
Radiation contraindicated in pregnancy; contrast imaging considerations; meningiomas may enlarge during pregnancy due to progesterone receptors

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: If parasellar or suprasellar meningioma compressing pituitary stalk; hyperprolactinemia from stalk effect
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Mildly elevated if stalk effect (<200 ng/mL); markedly elevated suggests prolactinoma

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: If parasellar meningioma with suspected pituitary axis compromise; baseline before dexamethasone
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal (>10 mcg/dL AM); low suggests hypopituitarism

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Growth hormone axis assessment if parasellar meningioma compressing pituitary
Pituitary axis assessment if parasellar meningioma; complement TSH
Gonadotropin axis assessment if parasellar meningioma; menstrual irregularity evaluation
If infection differential (epidural abscess, pachymeningitis); inflammatory markers
If syncope or seizure presentation; cardiac evaluation before surgery
Glycemic status before initiating prolonged dexamethasone; perioperative glucose optimization

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If multiple dural-based lesions raising concern for plasmacytoma or lymphoproliferative disorder
Neurosarcoidosis differential if dural-based enhancing mass
IgG4-related pachymeningitis differential if diffuse dural thickening
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal (<135 mg/dL); elevated in IgG4 disease

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If bilateral meningiomas or multiple meningiomas suggesting neurofibromatosis type 2; young patients with meningioma

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: SMARCE1, TRAF7, KLF4, AKT1, PIK3CA, SMO mutation panel
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Molecular profiling for treatment-refractory or recurrent atypical/anaplastic meningiomas; emerging targeted therapy targets
If clinical presentation suggests paraneoplastic syndrome; dural metastasis differential

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediately upon presentation for acute symptoms (seizure, headache, focal deficit, altered mental status)
Essential/First-line.target: Extra-axial hyperdense or isodense mass; calcification (20-25% of meningiomas); hyperostosis of adjacent bone; possible hemorrhage; midline shift; hydrocephalus

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (gadolinium) (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h of presentation; GOLD STANDARD for meningioma; for incidental findings: baseline MRI then observation
Essential/First-line.target: Homogeneously enhancing extra-axial dural-based mass; broad dural attachment; dural tail sign (60-72%); well-circumscribed margins; CSF cleft between tumor and brain; T2 signal variable (iso to hyperintense); calcification as signal voids; arterial supply from meningeal vessels; possible venous sinus invasion (parasagittal/falcine)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Essential/First-line.timing: If MRI contraindicated or unavailable; initial evaluation in ED
Essential/First-line.target: Homogeneously enhancing extra-axial mass; calcification; hyperostosis; may show bony invasion

Essential/First-line.timing: Pre-operative baseline; QTc assessment for anti-emetics
Pre-operative clearance; metastatic disease differential (dural metastases)

Extended.timing: Pre-operative for parasagittal and falcine meningiomas; assess venous sinus patency and degree of invasion
Extended.target: Patent vs. occluded sagittal sinus; degree of sinus invasion (partial vs. complete); collateral venous drainage pathways; critical for surgical planning
Extended.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Extended.timing: Pre-operative vascular mapping; large or vascular meningiomas; skull base tumors encasing major arteries
Extended.target: Arterial supply identification; ICA/vertebral artery encasement assessment; surgical planning for vascular control

Extended.timing: Pre-operative embolization planning for large vascular meningiomas; assess feeding vessels and collateral supply
Extended.target: Tumor blush; feeding arteries (MMA, occipital, APhA); degree of vascularity; potential for pre-operative embolization to reduce intraoperative blood loss
Extended.contraindications: Contrast allergy; renal impairment; coagulopathy; vascular access complications

Extended.timing: 24-48h before surgery for large hypervascular meningiomas; reduces intraoperative blood loss
Extended.target: Reduced tumor vascularity; confirmation of embolized feeding vessels
Extended.contraindications: Eloquent vessel supply; dangerous anastomoses (ECA to ICA); coagulopathy

Extended.timing: Sphenoid wing or optic nerve sheath meningioma with visual symptoms
Extended.target: Optic nerve compression; optic canal involvement; orbital extension
Extended.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Extended.timing: Baseline for parasellar, sphenoid wing, or optic nerve sheath meningiomas; monitor visual function pre and post treatment
Extended.target: Visual field deficit pattern (bitemporal hemianopia if chiasmal; homonymous if optic tract)

Extended.timing: Baseline for cerebellopontine angle (CPA) meningiomas or those involving internal auditory canal
Extended.target: Sensorineural hearing loss; speech discrimination score

Extended.timing: If NF2 suspected (multiple meningiomas); spinal symptoms suggesting spinal meningioma
Extended.target: Spinal meningiomas; drop metastases (very rare, grade III only)
Extended.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Rare/Specialized.timing: Atypical imaging features; differentiate meningioma from hemangiopericytoma/SFT, dural metastases, or lymphoma
Rare/Specialized.target: Elevated rCBV in meningioma; hemangiopericytoma may show higher rCBV; dural metastases variable
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Rare/Specialized.timing: Atypical imaging appearance; differentiate from other dural-based lesions
Rare/Specialized.target: Elevated alanine peak (characteristic of meningioma); elevated glutamine/glutamate; low NAA (extra-axial, no neuronal markers)
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Rare/Specialized.timing: Ga-68 DOTATATE: somatostatin receptor-positive meningioma detection; recurrence monitoring; treatment planning for peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT); FDG-PET: differentiate high-grade from low-grade meningioma
Rare/Specialized.target: DOTATATE: high uptake in meningioma (somatostatin receptor 2a positive); FDG: higher uptake in grade II/III vs. grade I

Rare/Specialized.timing: Somatostatin receptor expression assessment for potential somatostatin analog therapy in recurrent meningioma
Rare/Specialized.target: Positive uptake indicates somatostatin receptor expression (treatment target)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Vasogenic edema from meningioma; symptomatic mass effect; perioperative edema reduction; reduce peritumoral swelling to improve neurologic function

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV loading dose, then 4 mg IV/PO q6h; moderate symptoms: 4-8 mg/day; severe edema/herniation: 10 mg IV bolus then 4-8 mg q6h (up to 16-24 mg/day); taper as soon as clinically feasible over 1-2 weeks post-surgery; GI prophylaxis with PPI while on steroids

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes (relative); psychosis history (relative)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Glucose q6h (target <180 mg/dL), BP, mood/sleep, GI symptoms, signs of infection

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute seizure termination; seizures occur in 20-50% of convexity meningiomas

dosing.instructions: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg/dose); may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg total

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Acute narrow-angle glaucoma; severe respiratory depression without ventilator
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: RR, O2 sat, BP, sedation level; airway equipment at bedside

Acute/Emergent.indication: Anti-seizure medication loading for new seizures associated with meningioma; preferred due to no CYP enzyme induction and favorable safety profile

dosing.instructions: 1000-1500 mg IV load, then 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID; renal dosing if GFR <50

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: None absolute; reduce dose if CrCl <50
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Behavioral changes (agitation, irritability); generally well tolerated

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute elevated ICP with herniation signs from large meningioma; bridge to surgical intervention

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus over 15-20 min; may repeat 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h; maintain serum osmolality <320 mOsm/kg

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Anuria; severe dehydration; active intracranial bleeding (relative)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Serum osmolality q6h, serum sodium, I/O, renal function

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute elevated ICP from large meningioma; alternative to mannitol; may be preferred in hypotensive patients

dosing.instructions: 23.4% NaCl 30 mL via central line over 15 min OR 3% NaCl 250 mL IV over 30 min; target Na 145-155 mEq/L

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Sodium q4-6h, serum osmolality, I/O, central line required for 23.4%

Acute/Emergent.indication: DVT prophylaxis for surgical patients; meningioma surgery carries VTE risk especially with prolonged procedures

dosing.instructions: Enoxaparin 40 mg SC daily; start 24h post-operatively per neurosurgery; mechanical prophylaxis (SCDs) from admission until ambulatory

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active intracranial hemorrhage; planned surgery within 24h

Acute/Emergent.indication: GI bleed prevention while on dexamethasone; combined corticosteroid use increases risk

dosing.instructions: Pantoprazole 40 mg IV/PO daily OR omeprazole 20 mg PO daily; continue throughout steroid course

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Seizure prevention after first seizure from meningioma; NO prophylactic AEDs in patients without seizures unless high-risk perioperative period

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg BID; titrate by 500 mg/day q1-2 weeks to seizure control; max 3000 mg/day; renal dosing if GFR <50

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: None absolute; reduce dose if CrCl <50
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Behavioral changes (agitation, depression, irritability), somnolence; no drug interactions

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Alternative or adjunct AED for seizures from meningioma; minimal drug interactions

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg BID; titrate by 50 mg/dose weekly; max 400 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: PR interval >200 ms; 2nd/3rd degree AV block; severe hepatic impairment
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: ECG at baseline and with dose changes; PR interval monitoring

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Second-line AED for meningioma-related seizures; useful when levetiracetam not tolerated

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg BID; titrate by 250 mg q3-5 days to therapeutic level (50-100 mcg/mL); max 60 mg/kg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Hepatic disease; mitochondrial disorders (Alpers syndrome); pregnancy (teratogenic); urea cycle disorders; pancreatitis history
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: LFTs at baseline and periodically; ammonia if AMS; CBC (thrombocytopenia); VPA level

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Transition from IV to PO; taper after surgery as soon as clinically feasible to minimize steroid side effects

dosing.instructions: Taper by 2 mg every 3-5 days (e.g., 16 to 12 to 8 to 6 to 4 to 2 to 1 to off); slower taper if symptoms recur; monitor for adrenal insufficiency if >3 weeks of use

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Glucose, BP, mood, steroid myopathy (proximal weakness), immunosuppression

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea/vomiting from elevated ICP or perioperative

dosing.instructions: 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN nausea; max 24 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: QT prolongation; concurrent use of QT-prolonging agents
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: QTc if risk factors; serotonin syndrome risk with SSRIs

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache from tumor-associated edema or post-operative; avoid NSAIDs peri-operatively due to bleeding risk

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN headache; max 3 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Glucose management while on dexamethasone; hyperglycemia common with steroid use

dosing.instructions: Fingerstick glucose q6h; sliding scale insulin initially; basal-bolus if persistently >180 mg/dL; may need 2-3x baseline insulin on dexamethasone; anticipate glucose improvement as steroids taper

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Steroid-induced osteoporosis prevention if prolonged dexamethasone (>2 weeks) anticipated

doseOptions.orderSentence: Calcium + Vitamin D 1000 mg Ca + 800 IU Vit D PO

dosing.instructions: Calcium 1000-1200 mg + Vitamin D 800-1000 IU daily while on steroids
dosing.orderSentence: Calcium + Vitamin D 1000 mg Ca + 800 IU Vit D PO

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis if dexamethasone >20 mg/week AND concomitant temozolomide, bevacizumab, or other immunosuppression

dosing.instructions: TMP-SMX 1 DS tablet 3x/week (Mon/Wed/Fri); if sulfa allergic: atovaquone 1500 mg PO daily or dapsone 100 mg PO daily (check G6PD first)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Sulfa allergy (use alternative); severe renal impairment; megaloblastic anemia from folate deficiency
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: CBC q2-4 weeks; renal function; rash; report fever/dyspnea

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Short-course perioperative seizure prophylaxis for craniotomy in patients without seizure history; 7-day course only per institutional protocol; NOT recommended beyond 7 days without documented seizure

dosing.instructions: Levetiracetam 500 mg BID starting day of surgery; discontinue at 7 days post-operatively unless seizure occurs; if seizure occurs, convert to maintenance dosing

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: None absolute; reduce dose if CrCl <50

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Recurrent meningioma amenable to re-resection; symptomatic recurrence after initial surgery; Simpson grade-dependent recurrence risk

dosing.instructions: Maximal safe resection; Simpson Grade I (complete removal with dural attachment and abnormal bone) is goal when safely achievable; post-op MRI within 48h

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Poor functional status; eloquent location precluding safe resection; extensive dural sinus invasion
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Post-op MRI within 48h; neurologic exams; wound monitoring

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Recurrent/progressive meningioma refractory to surgery and radiation; anti-VEGF monoclonal antibody; limited evidence but some case series show stabilization

dosing.instructions: 10 mg/kg IV every 2 weeks; infuse first dose over 90 min, then 60 min, then 30 min if tolerated; continue until progression or intolerable toxicity

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension; recent surgery (28 days); active hemorrhage; bowel perforation risk; pregnancy; severe proteinuria (>3.5 g/24h)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: BP each visit; urinalysis for proteinuria q2-4 weeks; wound healing assessment; CBC; signs of GI perforation, thromboembolism

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Recurrent meningioma expressing somatostatin receptors (confirmed by octreotide scan or DOTATATE PET); limited evidence; some patients show disease stabilization

dosing.instructions: Octreotide LAR 30 mg IM every 4 weeks; may require dose adjustment based on response; continue if stable disease or objective response

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Gallbladder ultrasound q6 months; glucose monitoring; GI symptoms (diarrhea, abdominal pain); GH/IGF-1 levels

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Recurrent atypical or anaplastic meningioma (WHO grade II/III) refractory to surgery and radiation; limited evidence; consider when no clinical trial available

dosing.instructions: 150-200 mg/m2 PO days 1-5 of 28-day cycle; take on empty stomach 1h before bedtime; antiemetic pre-medication

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: ANC <1500; platelets <100K; severe hepatic/renal impairment; pregnancy
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC Day 1 and Day 22 of each cycle; LFTs monthly; limited efficacy data in meningioma

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Recurrent/progressive meningioma refractory to standard therapies; VEGFR/PDGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor; Kaley et al. showed PFS-6 of 42% in atypical/anaplastic meningioma

dosing.instructions: 50 mg PO daily for 28 days followed by 14-day rest (4/2 schedule); or 37.5 mg continuous daily schedule; dose reduce for toxicity

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension; hepatic impairment; QT prolongation; bleeding risk
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: BP weekly initially; CBC q2 weeks; LFTs; TSH q3 months; cardiac function (LVEF); hand-foot syndrome; diarrhea

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Progesterone receptor-positive meningioma (mostly WHO grade I); antiprogesterone therapy; SWOG S9005 showed no significant benefit overall but some individual responses

dosing.instructions: 200 mg PO daily continuously; efficacy data limited and conflicting

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Pregnancy (abortifacient); chronic adrenal failure; concurrent corticosteroid use for life-threatening conditions; hemorrhagic disorders
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Cortisol levels (adrenal insufficiency); potassium; endometrial thickness in women; vaginal bleeding

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.indication: Symptomatic meningioma; growing meningioma on serial imaging; large meningiomas (>3 cm) with mass effect; WHO grade II/III meningiomas; Simpson Grade I-III resection goal based on location

dosing.instructions: Approach depends on location: convexity (direct), parasagittal (with sinus evaluation), skull base (various approaches - subfrontal, pterional, retrosigmoid, transpetrosal); aim for Simpson Grade I (complete resection with dural attachment and involved bone) when safely achievable

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.pretreatment: Pre-operative MRI within 2 weeks; MRV for parasagittal tumors; CTA/DSA for vascular assessment of skull base tumors; consider pre-operative embolization for hypervascular tumors; medical optimization; DVT prophylaxis plan
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.contraindications: Poor surgical candidate (advanced age with significant comorbidities, KPS <50); tumor in surgically inaccessible location; patient preference for observation or radiation
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.monitoring: Post-op MRI within 48h; neurologic exams q2-4h for 24-48h; wound care; DVT prophylaxis; pain management; taper dexamethasone post-operatively

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.item: Stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) - Gamma Knife / CyberKnife / LINAC
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.indication: WHO grade I meningiomas <=3 cm not amenable to surgery or patient preference; residual/recurrent meningiomas after subtotal resection; cavernous sinus meningiomas (surgery high risk); adjuvant after subtotal resection of WHO grade II

doseOptions.orderSentence: Stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) - Gamma Knife / CyberKnife / LINAC 12-16 Gy -

dosing.instructions: 12-16 Gy to tumor margin in single fraction (typically 13-14 Gy for skull base; 14-16 Gy for convexity); dose depends on proximity to critical structures (optic chiasm <=8 Gy, brainstem <=12 Gy)
dosing.orderSentence: Stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) - Gamma Knife / CyberKnife / LINAC 12-16 Gy -

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.pretreatment: High-resolution MRI for treatment planning (thin-cut, contrast-enhanced); frame-based or frameless immobilization; pathologic confirmation preferred (especially if imaging atypical)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.contraindications: Tumor >3 cm (relative; may use fractionated SRT instead); too close to optic apparatus for single fraction (use fractionated); diffuse/en plaque meningioma
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.monitoring: MRI at 6 months, then annually for 5 years, then q2 years; monitor for radiation necrosis (1-3%); cranial nerve deficits (optic, trigeminal, facial depending on location)

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.indication: WHO grade I meningiomas >3 cm or near critical structures (optic chiasm, brainstem); WHO grade II after subtotal resection or recurrence; large skull base meningiomas

dosing.instructions: 50-54 Gy in 28-30 fractions (1.8 Gy/fraction) over 5-6 weeks; conforms to irregularly shaped tumors near critical structures

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.pretreatment: MRI-based treatment planning; immobilization mask fitting; adequate interval from surgery (typically 4-6 weeks)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.contraindications: Pregnancy; prior full-dose radiation to same area (assess cumulative dose)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.monitoring: MRI q6 months for 2 years, then annually; radiation necrosis risk; fatigue during treatment; alopecia at entry sites

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.item: Adjuvant radiation therapy (WHO grade II - atypical)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.indication: WHO grade II (atypical) meningioma after subtotal resection (Simpson grade IV-V); consider after gross total resection if high proliferation index (Ki-67 >10%) or brain invasion; reduces recurrence rate

doseOptions.orderSentence: Adjuvant radiation therapy (WHO grade II - atypical) 54-60 Gy -

dosing.instructions: 54-60 Gy in 30-33 fractions; begin 4-6 weeks after surgery; target tumor bed with margin
dosing.orderSentence: Adjuvant radiation therapy (WHO grade II - atypical) 54-60 Gy -

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.pretreatment: Post-operative MRI for treatment planning; adequate wound healing; pathologic confirmation of WHO grade II
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.contraindications: Pregnancy; prior full-dose radiation to same area (assess cumulative dose)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.monitoring: MRI q3-4 months for first 2 years, then q6 months; monitor for recurrence which is common in grade II (35-40% at 5 years even with treatment)

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.item: Adjuvant radiation therapy (WHO grade III - anaplastic)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.indication: WHO grade III (anaplastic/malignant) meningioma after any extent of resection; radiation indicated regardless of surgical completeness due to high recurrence rate (50-80% at 5 years)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Adjuvant radiation therapy (WHO grade III - anaplastic) 59.4-60 Gy -

dosing.instructions: 59.4-60 Gy in 33 fractions (1.8 Gy/fraction) over 6.5 weeks; some centers consider dose escalation; target tumor bed with 1-2 cm CTV margin
dosing.orderSentence: Adjuvant radiation therapy (WHO grade III - anaplastic) 59.4-60 Gy -

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.pretreatment: Post-operative MRI for treatment planning; pathologic confirmation of WHO grade III; molecular profiling
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.contraindications: Pregnancy; prior full-dose radiation to same area (assess cumulative dose)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.monitoring: MRI q2-3 months for first 2 years given high recurrence risk; close clinical follow-up; consider systemic therapy trials

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.indication: Asymptomatic incidental meningiomas (especially small <2 cm); elderly patients with slowly growing tumors; patient preference; no significant edema or mass effect

dosing.instructions: MRI at 3 months (first scan), then 6 months, then annually for 5 years, then q2 years if stable; intervene if growth >2-3 mm/year, development of symptoms, or new edema

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.pretreatment: Baseline MRI with volumetric assessment; patient counseling about observation rationale and surveillance plan; reliable patient for follow-up
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.contraindications: Not appropriate for symptomatic meningiomas, WHO grade II/III, or rapidly growing tumors
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Surgery / R.monitoring: MRI per schedule; clinical assessment at each visit; patient education on symptoms warranting urgent evaluation (new headache, seizure, focal deficit)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurosurgery consultation for surgical candidacy evaluation, resection planning, and assessment of Simpson grade achievability based on tumor location and vascular involvement
Radiation oncology consultation for SRS, fSRT, or adjuvant radiation planning in patients with WHO grade II/III meningioma, residual tumor after surgery, or meningioma not amenable to resection
Neuro-oncology consultation for WHO grade II/III meningioma management, systemic therapy options for recurrent/refractory disease, and clinical trial enrollment
Multidisciplinary tumor board presentation for coordinated treatment planning including neurosurgery, radiation oncology, neuro-oncology, neuropathology, and neuroradiology
Neuro-ophthalmology consultation for visual field deficits, papilledema, or optic nerve/chiasm compression from parasellar, sphenoid wing, or olfactory groove meningioma
Ophthalmology for formal visual field testing (Humphrey perimetry) baseline and follow-up if tumor near visual pathways
Endocrinology consultation for pituitary axis evaluation if parasellar meningioma causing hormonal dysfunction, or for steroid-induced hyperglycemia management
ENT/Otolaryngology for hearing assessment and management if CPA meningioma with auditory symptoms
Physical therapy for mobility assessment, fall prevention given neurologic deficits and steroid myopathy, and post-operative rehabilitation
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive compensation strategies, and home safety evaluation
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation if posterior fossa or skull base meningioma with cranial nerve involvement, and language assessment if dominant hemisphere tumor
Social work consultation for insurance authorization, disability paperwork, caregiver support, and community resource coordination
Neuropsychology evaluation for baseline cognitive assessment if tumor in eloquent cortex, before radiation, or if cognitive complaints
Genetic counseling if multiple meningiomas, bilateral meningiomas, or age <40 years for NF2 screening
Palliative care consultation for WHO grade III meningioma or recurrent progressive disease for symptom management and goals of care discussion

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for new or worsening headache, sudden weakness, vision changes, speech difficulty, or seizures (may indicate tumor progression, hemorrhage, or increased edema)
Do not drive until cleared by neurology and neurosurgery due to seizure risk and visual field deficits
Do not stop dexamethasone abruptly as this may cause adrenal crisis; follow prescribed taper schedule exactly
Report any new vision changes (blurring, double vision, visual field loss) as this may indicate tumor growth or post-treatment edema requiring urgent evaluation
For observed (watchful waiting) patients: attend all scheduled MRI surveillance appointments as recommended; growth may occur without symptoms initially
Wear medical alert identification indicating brain tumor diagnosis and seizure risk if history of seizures
Keep a symptom diary documenting headaches, seizures, vision changes, weakness, and cognitive changes to track disease course
Report any fever, wound swelling, or drainage after surgery as this may indicate post-operative infection requiring urgent treatment
Post-SRS/radiation: report any new or worsening neurologic symptoms (may indicate radiation-induced edema or necrosis, typically at 3-12 months post-treatment)
For women of childbearing age: meningiomas may grow during pregnancy; discuss family planning with neurosurgeon and OB/GYN before conception

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Low-sodium diet while on dexamethasone to reduce fluid retention, edema, and hypertension
Blood sugar monitoring and diabetic diet while on steroids to prevent steroid-induced hyperglycemia complications
Regular low-impact exercise (walking, swimming, yoga) as tolerated to maintain strength, reduce steroid myopathy, and improve quality of life
Fall precautions at home including removal of trip hazards, use of handrails, non-slip mats, and night lights given focal deficits and seizure risk
Smoking cessation to optimize wound healing and surgical outcomes

Avoid exogenous hormones (hormone replacement therapy, oral contraceptives with progesterone) as meningiomas express progesterone receptors and may grow with hormonal stimulation; discuss with OB/GYN for alternatives
CPAP compliance if obstructive sleep apnea present to prevent nocturnal hypoxia which may worsen cerebral edema
Adequate hydration (2-3 L/day unless fluid restricted) to support renal function particularly if undergoing contrast imaging studies
Sun protection during radiation therapy course due to scalp sensitivity
Weight-bearing exercise and calcium/vitamin D supplementation for bone health if on prolonged steroids

differential.features: History of systemic malignancy (breast, lung, prostate most common); often multiple dural-based lesions; may lack the classic dural tail or show irregular enhancement; leptomeningeal involvement more common; known primary malignancy
differential.tests: CT chest/abdomen/pelvis for primary site; PET/CT; biopsy showing non-meningothelial histology (cytokeratin, TTF-1, etc.); clinical history of known cancer

differential.features: WHO grade 2 or 3; narrow dural attachment (vs. broad base of meningioma); prominent flow voids; heterogeneous enhancement; more aggressive; higher recurrence and metastasis risk
differential.tests: MR perfusion (very high rCBV); angiography showing dense tumor blush; biopsy with STAT6 nuclear positivity (defining marker); CD34 positive; lack of EMA/progesterone receptor expression

differential.features: Rare dural presentation; homogeneous enhancement; restricted diffusion on DWI; may respond dramatically to corticosteroids; immunocompromised patients at higher risk
differential.tests: DWI showing restricted diffusion; CSF flow cytometry; stereotactic biopsy; HIV testing; typically B-cell markers positive; avoid steroids before biopsy

differential.features: Diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement; may be focal mimicking meningioma; systemic sarcoidosis features; elevated ACE level; hilar lymphadenopathy
differential.tests: Serum ACE level; chest CT (bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy); CSF analysis; biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas; tissue ACE immunostaining; FDG-PET for systemic disease

differential.features: Diffuse dural thickening and enhancement; may mimic en plaque meningioma; often involves other organs (pancreas, salivary glands, orbits); responds to corticosteroids initially
differential.tests: Serum IgG4 level; dural biopsy showing IgG4-positive plasma cells (>10/HPF); IgG4/IgG ratio >40%; storiform fibrosis; obliterative phlebitis

differential.features: Dural-based mass with pachymeningeal thickening; sinunasal involvement; may present with cranial neuropathies; systemic vasculitis features
differential.tests: ANCA (cANCA/PR3); sinus CT showing mucosal disease; biopsy showing necrotizing granulomatous inflammation; renal function

differential.features: Can cause dural enhancement mimicking meningioma; venous hypertension; pulsatile tinnitus; hemorrhage risk; associated with venous sinus thrombosis
differential.tests: MRA/MRV showing abnormal flow voids; catheter angiography is gold standard (shows fistula with early venous filling); lack of solid mass component

differential.features: Solitary or multiple dural-based lesions; may erode bone; lytic skull lesions; elevated serum protein
differential.tests: SPEP/UPEP; serum free light chains; bone marrow biopsy; skeletal survey; biopsy showing plasma cell neoplasm; CD138 positive

differential.features: Rare; dural-based mass mimicking meningioma; may have lymphadenopathy; young adults
differential.tests: Biopsy showing emperipolesis (lymphocytes within histiocyte cytoplasm); S100 positive, CD68 positive; CD1a negative

differential.features: Typically arises from cranial nerves; may appear dural-based at skull base (especially CPA); heterogeneous enhancement; cystic components common
differential.tests: MRI: arising from cranial nerve (vs. dural attachment); internal auditory canal widening if vestibular schwannoma; biopsy showing S100 positive, EMA negative (opposite of meningioma)

evidence.recommendation: MRI with gadolinium is the gold standard imaging for meningioma diagnosis and surgical planning
Simpson grading system for extent of resection predicts recurrence risk
Gross total resection (Simpson Grade I) provides best local control for WHO grade I meningioma
evidence.source: [Meling et al. Neurosurg Rev 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30684722/); [Gousias et al. J Neurosurg 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26824369/)

evidence.recommendation: Stereotactic radiosurgery achieves 90-95% local control for WHO grade I meningiomas at 10 years
evidence.source: [Kondziolka et al. J Neurosurg 1999](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10389879/); [Pollock et al. J Neurosurg 2003](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12816261/)

evidence.recommendation: SRS marginal dose of 12-16 Gy recommended for meningiomas; higher doses associated with better control
evidence.source: [Flickinger et al. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 2003](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12788188/)

evidence.recommendation: WHO 2021 classification defines meningioma grading (Grade I, II, III) based on histologic criteria
WHO grade II (atypical) meningioma has 35-40% recurrence at 5 years; adjuvant RT reduces recurrence
evidence.source: [Rogers et al. J Neurosurg 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25679280/); [Komotar et al. J Neurooncol 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23160390/)

evidence.recommendation: NRC/RTOG 0539: risk-adapted radiation for meningiomas; intermediate-risk (recurrent grade I, new grade II) benefit from adjuvant RT
Observation is appropriate for small asymptomatic incidental meningiomas with serial MRI surveillance
evidence.source: [Yano et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18181407/); [Oya et al. J Neurosurg 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30746239/)

evidence.recommendation: Meningioma growth rate averages 2-4 mm/year; 63-75% remain stable or grow slowly on observation
Bevacizumab shows limited activity in recurrent meningioma; some disease stabilization
evidence.source: [Nayak et al. Neuro-Oncology 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24426201/); [Lou et al. J Neurooncol 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27774404/)

evidence.recommendation: Sunitinib shows PFS-6 of 42% in recurrent atypical/anaplastic meningioma
Prophylactic AEDs NOT recommended in meningioma patients without seizures
Levetiracetam preferred AED in brain tumor patients due to no enzyme induction
Dexamethasone effective for peritumoral vasogenic edema; use minimum effective dose and taper
MRV essential for preoperative planning of parasagittal meningiomas to assess sinus invasion
Pre-operative embolization reduces intraoperative blood loss for hypervascular meningiomas
Ga-68 DOTATATE PET superior to conventional imaging for meningioma detection and treatment planning
Meningiomas express progesterone receptors; exogenous hormone use may promote growth
EANO guidelines for meningioma diagnosis and management
evidence.source: [Goldbrunner et al. Lancet Oncol 2021](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34181733/) (EANO guideline update)

evidence.recommendation: NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines for CNS Cancers: Meningioma section

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (motor, sensory, language, cognition, cranial nerves, visual fields)
monitoring.action: STAT MRI if decline; increase dexamethasone; neurosurgery alert if herniation

monitoring.frequency: q6h while on dexamethasone (q1h if insulin drip)
monitoring.action: Sliding scale to basal-bolus insulin; endocrine consult if refractory

monitoring.frequency: Within 48h of surgery (new baseline); then at 3 months, 6 months, 12 months
monitoring.action: If residual: radiation oncology referral; if recurrence: tumor board

monitoring.item: MRI brain with contrast (WHO grade I - observation)
monitoring.frequency: 3 months (baseline), 6 months, then annually for 5 years, then q2 years if stable
monitoring.action: Growth >2-3 mm/year: consider intervention (surgery or SRS)

monitoring.item: MRI brain with contrast (WHO grade I - post-treatment)
monitoring.frequency: 6 months, then annually for 5 years, then q2 years
monitoring.action: Recurrence: tumor board for re-resection, radiation, or observation

monitoring.item: MRI brain with contrast (WHO grade II)
monitoring.frequency: q3-4 months for first 2 years, then q6 months for years 3-5, then annually
monitoring.action: Recurrence: multidisciplinary re-evaluation; consider re-resection, re-irradiation, systemic therapy

monitoring.item: MRI brain with contrast (WHO grade III)
monitoring.frequency: q2-3 months for first 2 years, then q3-4 months for years 3-5
monitoring.action: Recurrence: urgent tumor board; systemic therapy, clinical trials

monitoring.frequency: Baseline pre-treatment; 3 months post-treatment; then annually if near visual pathways
monitoring.action: Urgent MRI if new deficits; ophthalmology reassessment

monitoring.frequency: Baseline for CPA meningiomas; 6 months and annually post-treatment
monitoring.action: ENT referral for hearing aid evaluation; assess for radiation injury vs. recurrence

monitoring.frequency: q6 months for parasellar meningiomas; annually after treatment
monitoring.action: Hormone replacement as needed; endocrinology follow-up

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU; q4h on floor; each clinic visit
monitoring.action: Antihypertensives; especially monitor if on steroids
SIADH workup if <130; DI workup if >150 post-op; fluid management

monitoring.frequency: Continuous inpatient if seizure history; patient diary outpatient
monitoring.action: AED dose adjustment; verify compliance; EEG if subclinical suspected

disposition.criteria: GCS <=12; signs of herniation (pupil asymmetry, posturing, Cushing triad); acute hemorrhage into tumor; status epilepticus; post-craniotomy (first 24h per institutional protocol); respiratory compromise requiring intubation; large skull base resection with cranial nerve monitoring needs

New diagnosis with symptomatic edema requiring IV dexamethasone; post-craniotomy step-down from ICU (typically POD 1-2); seizures requiring AED optimization; functional decline requiring inpatient rehabilitation planning; pre-operative workup and embolization
Known meningioma with mild symptom worsening; post-SRS monitoring (typically outpatient but observation if large or eloquent location); steroid dose adjustment

Neurologically stable for >=24h; seizure-free >=24h on oral AED; oral dexamethasone taper plan established with written instructions; pain controlled on oral medications; outpatient follow-up scheduled (neurosurgery and/or radiation oncology within 2-4 weeks); safe ambulation or adequate caregiver; wound care instructions if post-operative

Asymptomatic incidental finding; MRI baseline obtained or ordered; observation plan established with surveillance MRI schedule; neurosurgery outpatient referral within 4-6 weeks; return precautions provided
Need for neurosurgical expertise not available (especially skull base surgery); need for SRS/radiation not available; tumor board or neuro-oncology consultation not available; clinical trial access
Significant post-operative neurologic deficits requiring intensive rehabilitation (hemiparesis, aphasia, cranial nerve deficits); KPS 40-60 with rehabilitation potential
End-stage WHO grade III meningioma with progressive decline; exhausted reasonable treatment options; patient/family goals aligned with comfort care
